perturbation.original_text: 1.1     "SOFTWARE USER" means a named user of the Corio Services worldwide to         whom a user identification number and password has been assigned, which         permits that user to access and use the Software on a designated Corio         Server. The identification number and password used by a Software User         is reusable and reassignable and may be used and transferred by Corio,         in accordance with the licenses granted below, between Customers as one         Customer discontinues the Corio Services and another Customer         subscribes.
perturbation.changed_text: 1.1     "SOFTWARE USER" means any individual, whether or not a named user, accessing the Corio Services worldwide, with or without assigned credentials, permitting access and usage of the Software on a Corio Server. The credentials, if any, used by a Software User may or may not be reusable, reassignable, or transferable by Corio between Customers.
perturbation.explanation: The original definition clearly defines a 'SOFTWARE USER' as a 'named user' with 'assigned credentials'. The modified definition broadens this to 'any individual' even without assigned credentials, thus contradicting the original intent and creating ambiguity about who is considered a 'SOFTWARE USER' under the contract. This is a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Ambiguity in definition leading to unenforceability.

perturbation.original_text: 2.1     Hosting Software License. Subject to the terms and conditions of this         Agreement, Commerce One hereby grants to Corio a fee-bearing, perpetual         and irrevocable, nonexclusive, nontransferable (except in accordance         with Section 14.1 of this Agreement), right and license in the Territory         to (i) reproduce the Software in machine executable object code format         only for installation on the Corio Servers; (ii) install multiple copies         of the Software on Corio's Servers which will be made remotely         accessible to Corio's Customers for their subsequent use, (iii) permit         limited access to and use of the Software and MarketSite.net Service by         Customers through Corio Servers; (iv) sublicense an unlimited number of         Customers to access and use the Software and MarketSite.net Service only         through the installation on Corio servers; and (v) use Commerce One's         tools and utilities, subject to any restrictions placed on the Commerce         One by third party software providers, to modify and manage the         Software. perturbation.changed_text: 2.1     Hosting Software License. Subject to the terms and conditions of this         Agreement, Commerce One hereby grants to Corio a potentially revocable, exclusive, transferable right and license in the Territory to (i) reproduce the Software in source code format for installation on servers as Corio sees fit; (ii) install an undefined number of copies of the Software; (iii) permit unlimited access to and use of the Software and MarketSite.net Service by anyone; (iv) sublicense anyone to access and use the Software and MarketSite.net Service through any means; and (v) use Commerce One's tools and utilities without restriction to modify and manage the Software. Corio is implicitly granted the right to distribute the Software to its Customers or for use other than as part of the Corio Services.
perturbation.explanation: This section originally grants a very specific license to Corio. The modified version introduces several conflicting elements, such as making the license 'potentially revocable' (vs. 'perpetual and irrevocable'), 'exclusive' (vs. 'nonexclusive'), and 'transferable' (vs. 'nontransferable'). It also changes the permitted use, removing limitations on access, sublicense, and distribution, thus directly contradicting the originally defined scope of the license.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Contradictory terms regarding license rights create ambiguity, leading to potential unenforceability.
